Award.AwardTitle: CDS&E: The development of open-source software with an application to modeling the formation of globular star clusters
Award.AbstractNarration:
Globular star clusters are among the oldest objects in our Universe, and understanding their origin has remained a great challenge to astrophysicists for many decades. This project will develop computer software employing a new numerical method to perform the calculations modeling the formation of these clusters of stars. This new computer software will enable better computer modeling of the astrophysics governing a variety of physical applications. It will also be the first such software to be made publicly available. The investigators will then use this software to create computer simulations that model the formation of globular star clusters, and they specifically seek to understand the apparent creation of multiple generations of stars in these globular clusters. This project's goals will advance the national interests of developing US leadership in physics and enhancing the US cyber infrastructure. In addition, the investigators will address the national underrepresentation of minorities in the sciences by funding a graduate student to participate in Columbia University's Bridge to the PhD in the Natural Sciences program. The investigators will train the student in the research program and will mentor the student through the early stages of his or her science career.

More technically, the first part of this project lays out a systematic plan to develop a new open source moving-mesh code. Recent development of the moving-mesh method as a viable alternative to smoothed particle hydrodynamics and adaptive mesh refinement is a promising development. Moving-mesh hydrodynamics brings many desirable features including low-diffusion in bulk flows, Galilean invariance, and good shock handling. The software development uses modern design and coding techniques to produce an efficient, parallel code that will be capable of using a wide range of physics and that is easy to use and modify. It will use the widely used Python language combined with Cython (a static Python compiler) in computationally intensive parts. Coding will be modular and designed to allow easy and flexible extension to all parts of the code. The second part of this project is to simulate the formation of globular clusters. The code will be applied to a three-part plan for understanding globular cluster formation: (1) modeling the fragmentation and collapse of idealized low-metallicity gas clouds to understand the relative importance of global collapse and fragmentation; (2) using cosmological simulations to identify the physical properties of gas undergoing rapid colliding flows, a prerequisite to bring together a large amount of gas in a small region for GC formation; and (3) exploring the ability of gas outflows from the proposed sources of enriched material to be re-incorporated into a second generation of stars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have developed a new open-source software package (phd-code.github.io) that solves the equations of fluid dynamics on a mesh which can move and deform in order to better track the evolution of the gas. In particular, we have implemented an Arbitrary Lagrangian-Eulerian (ALE) technique that uses mesh-generating points that try to move the grid along with the flow of the gas, in order to minimize the amount of gas that must be transferred from cell to cell as the grid evolves, and hence the diffusive errors that arise during this advection process. The code is written in Python, a widely used programming language, to improve readability and ease of development, with some components in Cython (a superset of Python) to enhance performance. The code is parallelized with MPI and includes self-gravity and a range of test problems. It has been written in a highly modular, object-oriented way, in order to make the code more flexible and easier to extend to new problems. As part of this grant, we have also developed an open-source code for computing the radiative cooling rate of astrophysical gas, called The Grackle (grackle.readthedocs.io).

In addition to the code development, we have studied the formation and evolution of small galaxies forming in the early universe that have had very little or no enrichment of heavy elements. These galaxies, which give rise to some of the first stars and black holes are of particular interest because they are the first sources of heavy elements, they tell us about the early history of the universe, and because the products of these stars may be detectable today. The stars in these galaxies are thought to be particularly massive (a hundred times our own sun) because of the inefficient radiative cooling due to the absence of heavy elements.

We studied a number of aspects of this problem. One area involved an improved understanding of the role of molecular hydrogen in the formation of the first galaxies. In particular, we have studied the process by which radiation arising from the transitions between the ground and first excited states of hydrogen during the collapse of the gas clouds that formed these stars. The photons coming from that transition can destroy molecular hydrogen, preventing the gas from cooling below 10 000 K and leading to supermassive stars that may end their lives in particularly large black holes. We also looked at the role that infrared radiation from other stars can play in dissociating H-, a key ingredient in the formation of molecular hydrogen. Ionizing radiation from nearby bright galaxies can also delay the collapse of an unenriched cloud even more, until the cloud is sufficiently large that it can block out the ionizing radiation, allowing the rapid collapse of a large amount of gas into a cluster of ?first stars?.

In addition to these primordial stars, we also carried out numerical investigations of dense star forming regions that could give rise to globular clusters, which are groups of millions of stars tightly packed in a region with a radius of the distance to the sun?s nearest neighbor. We demonstrated that at low, but non-zero, levels of heavy elements, slow gas cooling can allow gas clouds to slowly collapse to these high densities before fragmenting into small regions, as found in present-day globular clusters. We also ran a set of simulations to characterize the size a gas cloud must attain before it can cool and allow stars to form as a function of time, radiation background, and the relative motion of dark matter.

A third thrust of this project was to develop a framework to model and follow the formation of individual stars within a galaxy, including their stellar evolution and, where appropriate, stellar winds and explosive events (like supernovae) which returned mass and heavy elements to the rest of the galaxy. This code also followed a wide range of these elements, allowing us to determine the rate at which they mix and, in some cases, escape from the galaxy due to galactic winds. We demonstrate that different heavy elements were lost at different rates depending on their source (low velocity winds from evolved stars or high velocity ejecta from supernovae).
